meeting_annotations.transcript: On this hybrid approach is another example I can give is that we do here in wealth quite a bit is the production of biochar and then trying to use the biochar to replace coke in steel making. meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, one thing I can sort of add to the carbon tech story that we were talking at the beginning is that we have the person who wants to buy the carbon credit, then we have the person doing the sequestration, then we have the market, which is doing the financial transaction. So the third party verification needs to have experimental methodologies or simulation software or lifecycle analysis tools to verify that everything that is going on in that in that circle is is actually true. So and and that's something that we need a lot of. I'm I'm part of the peer review board member of Nori, which is the carbon market that's most active right now in the US. And what they are relying currently on is something called, I think it's called Comet. Right? So it's a software that simulates if you do this and this and this to your soil, this will be how much carbon you're sequestering. So it's based on a lot of assumptions and it's based on, yeah, a huge amount of uncertainty. But that's the best they have right now. So that's what they're relying on.
